about.title: What GuardianMap does
about.text: GuardianMap highlights truly responsible marine activities, promotes those with official labels, and co-creates ethical tours with committed local agencies. Awareness is also at the core of our work through ocean-focused articles, strengthening collective consciousness for nature-respectful tourism.

oman.title: Oman: protect, be patient‚Ä¶ and live magical encounters
oman.subtitle: An exemplary country: regulated turtle access, protected Daymaniyat Islands, natural encounters without feeding.
oman.heroAlt: Oman: Daymaniyat Islands, turtles, reef sharks
oman.p1: If there is a destination where true respect for wildlife is felt, it‚Äôs Oman. Encounters happen on nature‚Äôs terms. Authorities actively protect sea turtles and coastal ecosystems; visitors are invited to slow down ‚Äî for better encounters.
oman.h2_turtles: Sea turtles: regulated access for their peace
oman.p2: To watch turtles you must pay an access fee ‚Äî funding protection and monitoring. During nesting season, some beaches/islands are closed to tourists to avoid disturbing nesting or hatchlings. Result: less stress and preserved natural behaviour.
oman.h2_daymaniyat: Daymaniyat Islands: reef sharks‚Ä¶ without feeding
oman.p3: Around the Daymaniyat Islands you may meet reef sharks in a 100% natural setting: they are not fed. Boats keep their distance; you enter the water and swim to viewing zones. Sometimes you must be patient ‚Äî which is good: it prevents imbalance and makes the moment even more magical.
oman.h2_philosophy: A simple philosophy: see without disturbing
oman.li2: Respect distances and limit group sizes when needed.
oman.li3: Clear briefings and local guides who know the sites.
oman.quote: In Oman, patience is a virtue: the show is natural, unpredictable ‚Äî and unforgettable.

ws.title: Whale sharks: fragile beauty, shared responsibility
ws.subtitle: Why encounters must remain natural and how to observe without harm.
ws.heroAlt: Whale shark observed in its natural habitat
ws.intro_p1: In the vast blue of our oceans lives a gentle giant: the whale shark (Rhincodon typus).
ws.intro_p2: With its 12-meter length, a huge mouth filtering plankton, and a star-speckled back, it fascinates divers worldwide. Despite its size, this shark is harmless to humans: it feeds on micro-organisms, moves slowly, and embodies serenity.
ws.intro_p3: But this beauty,almost mythical, is also what puts it at risk today.
ws.attraction_p1: In several regions (Philippines, Mexico, Maldives, Mozambique, Thailand), the whale shark has become a true attraction. Some operators promise a ‚Äú100% chance‚Äù of seeing one.
ws.attraction_p2: Yet no encounter in the wild can ever be guaranteed. When a company claims certainty, it almost always means the animals are artificially fed to ensure their presence.
ws.attraction_p3: This practice, sadly widespread, has serious long-term consequences on behavior and health.
ws.carouselCaption: Glances of whale sharks in different regions (always follow local rules and guidelines).
ws.derives_intro: Feeding whale sharks is not benign. In the short term, it looks harmless: the animal approaches, visitors leave amazed. In the long term, the impacts are damaging:
ws.derives_li1: Behavioral disruption: dependence on feeding hotspots.
ws.derives_li2: Reduced migration: altered routes impacting reproduction and population health.
ws.derives_li3: Frequent injuries: propeller strikes or repeated contact with visitors.
ws.derives_li4: Health risks: unsuitable food disturbing metabolism.
ws.derives_outro: What starts as good intentions can end up harming their natural balance.
ws.practices_li1: Choose eco-certified operators (e.g., Green Fins or PADI Eco Center) or tours that do not guarantee a sighting.
ws.practices_li2: Never touch or feed the animal.
ws.practices_li3: Respect distances: at least 3‚Äì4 m from the head and 6 m from the tail.
ws.practices_li4: Limit the number of divers/boats present at the same time.
ws.practices_li6: Check natural seasons/areas where whale sharks aggregate.
ws.practices_outro: A respectful encounter is authentic and rare and all the more magical.
ws.orgs_mmf: Marine Megafauna Foundation (MMF) : Mozambique-based; long-term monitoring, photo-ID, and outreach. marinemegafauna.org
ws.orgs_sos: Save Our Seas Foundation : funds scientific and educational projects on sharks and rays. saveourseas.com
ws.orgs_wildbook: Whale Shark Project (Wild Me / Wildbook for Whale Sharks) : a global platform using spot patterns for individual identification.
ws.conclusion_p1: The whale shark symbolizes the fragility of beauty. It reminds us that fascination should never turn into domination.
ws.conclusion_p2: Every photo, every dive, every encounter can be an act of respect or disturbance. The choice is ours.
ws.quote: Loving the ocean also means learning to protect it.
ws.cta: Find truly responsible dive centers here: guardianmap.com/plong√©e

wmd.title: World Maritime Day: why maritime matters to everyone
wmd.subtitle: An IMO/UN day highlighting shipping‚Äôs vital role, safety at sea and ocean protection.
wmd.p1: World Maritime Day was created by the International Maritime Organization (IMO). It is celebrated annually, usually on the last Thursday of September.
wmd.p2: Goals: highlight shipping‚Äôs importance ‚Äî 80‚Äì90% of trade moves by sea ‚Äî and recognize seafarers, while raising awareness on environment, safety and innovation.
wmd.p3: Each edition proposes a specific theme (pollution prevention, energy transition, digitalization, ship safety, etc.).

pj1.title: 1) Decarbonization in Singapore ‚Äî marine biofuel trials (GCMD)
pj1.text: In Singapore, the Global Centre for Maritime Decarbonisation (GCMD) ran real-world trials with biofuels (B20‚ÄìB30). Aims: cut GHGs and validate interoperability (fuel quality, engines, bunkering, performance).
pj1.b2: Impact: measured emission cuts on commercial routes.

pj2.title: 2) Underwater noise reduction ‚Äî IMO guidelines (GloNoise)
pj2.text: Underwater noise affects fish and marine mammals. GloNoise supports applying IMO guidelines: monitoring, design integration, and operational good practices.
pj2.b2: Impact: noise mitigation in biodiversity hotspots.

pj3.title: 3) Nigeria ‚Äî awareness against plastic pollution (NIMASA)
pj3.text: NIMASA ran local campaigns: schools, calls to cut single-use plastics, and promotion of sustainable opportunities tied to a healthy sea.
pj3.b1: Scope: coastal communities, schools, local authorities.

wmd.h2_why: Why talk about it on GuardianMap?
wmd.why1: Our coastal and diving activities rely on a healthy ocean.
wmd.why2: Cleaner, safer shipping lanes benefit biodiversity and coastal communities.
wmd.why3: Understanding these issues helps us travel better and support responsible operators.
wmd.quote: Protecting the ocean also means caring about how our goods move and those who make the sea economy run.

coraux.title: White corals are not necessarily dead: understand, act, protect
coraux.subtitle: Bleaching ‚â† immediate death: it‚Äôs a stress signal. Understanding this nuance changes everything for reef protection.
coraux.h2_bleaching: Bleaching: a distress signal, not immediate death
coraux.p1: When a coral turns white, many people assume it is already dead. Yet a bleached coral is not necessarily doomed. Bleaching is primarily a stress response: when water temperature rises or the environment deteriorates, corals expel their symbiotic microalgae, the zooxanthellae, which give them color and provide a large share of their energy.
coraux.p2: As long as the coral is still alive, it can take the algae back if conditions become favorable again. Reefs that experienced mass bleaching have sometimes shown remarkable recovery, especially when heat stress drops quickly or local pressures decrease.
coraux.h2_when_die: When does a bleached coral actually die?
coraux.p3: If stress persists for several weeks, the coral runs out of energy and may die. A dead coral often appears bright chalky white before being covered by opportunistic algae.

box1.title: Why this happens more and more today
box1.b1: More frequent and more intense marine heatwaves (climate change).
box1.b2: Pollution, turbidity, overfishing, anchoring, and diseases.
box1.b3: Toxic sunscreens and unsuitable tourism practices.

coraux.quote: A white coral is not a dead coral: it can be alive, weakened, but still recoverable.
coraux.h2_how_help: How to support coral survival and recovery
coraux.p4: Recovery depends on two levers: reducing global stress (climate) and limiting local pressures. Even if we can‚Äôt directly control ocean temperatures, we can reduce local impacts that make things worse.

box2.title: Concretely, you can act on:
box2.b3: Improving tourism practices (no contact, good buoyancy, no anchoring on reefs).

coraux.h2_cg: Coral Guardian: an organization bringing reefs back to life

cg.p1: Coral Guardian is a French NGO founded in 2012, built around a strong idea: reef protection works best when local communities become the first guardians.
cg.h3: Their approach relies on three pillars:
cg.b1: Ecological restoration: replanting fragments of resilient corals.
cg.b3: Economic involvement: creating sustainable incomes linked to conservation.
cg.p2: On Hatamin Island (Indonesia), community-based restoration has replanted over 100,000 corals and led to a clear return of biodiversity.

coraux.h2_conclusion: Conclusion: a nuance that changes everything
coraux.p5: Bleaching is an alarm. A bleached reef can still be saved if pressures decrease and conditions stabilize. Understanding this nuance helps avoid fatalism‚Äîand strengthens better choices in the field, while traveling, and in daily life.

turtles.title: Green turtles are no longer listed as endangered: a win‚Ä¶ but a fragile one
turtles.subtitle: Real progress thanks to conservation ‚Äî but major threats still remain. Collective vigilance is essential.
turtles.h2_threatened: A species that was long threatened
turtles.p1: For a long time, the green turtle (Chelonia mydas) was one of the strongest symbols of marine species in trouble. Intensively hunted for meat, eggs and shell, threatened by the loss of nesting beaches, and impacted by bycatch in fishing nets, it was listed among endangered species.
turtles.p2: Today, a hopeful signal has emerged: green turtles are no longer officially classified as ‚ÄúEndangered‚Äù. The IUCN now places them in the ‚ÄúVulnerable‚Äù category, indicating a positive recovery trend.
turtles.h2_recovery: A remarkable improvement thanks to conservation
turtles.p3: This status change is the direct result of decades of effort: strict protection of nesting beaches, bans on international trade of shells, improved fishing practices through Turtle Excluder Devices, and the crucial involvement of local communities.
turtles.p4: In some countries, nest numbers have increased tenfold over twenty years. Beaches that were once deserted now welcome hundreds of nesting females again. It is one of the most encouraging ecological success stories of our time.
turtles.h2_caution: A victory to put in perspective: threats are still present

threats.intro: Despite this progress, green turtles are far from safe. They are still exposed to major threats:
threats.li1: Climate change: hotter sand (sex ratio imbalance), sea-level rise, storms destroying nests.
threats.li2: Mass tourism: disturbance of nesting beaches, boat strikes, pollution.
threats.li3: Fishing: bycatch still kills thousands of individuals every year.

turtles.p5: Even with these threats, the green turtle story is a powerful example of what conservation can achieve. When laws are enforced, scientists are listened to, local communities are involved, and travelers adopt responsible behaviors, nature can recover.
turtles.h2_role: What each of us can do
turtles.p6: Travelers can contribute too: choose ethical activities, avoid disturbing turtles on beaches or at sea, reduce plastic waste, support conservation programs ‚Äî or simply learn and share the right information.
turtles.quote: Green turtles are no longer in immediate danger ‚Äî but they still depend heavily on our collective vigilance.
turtles.h2_conclusion: Conclusion: a fragile victory and a call for vigilance
turtles.p7: The green turtle‚Äôs reclassification is a rare victory, the result of global efforts. But it remains fragile. Recovery can be reversed, and the future of the species depends on maintaining strong protections over time.

history.title: Why did we create GuardianMap?
history.intro: Many travelers don‚Äôt always know the right behaviors to adopt around the ocean. We want to see marine beauty‚Ä¶ but sometimes we unintentionally contribute to its destruction. GuardianMap helps clarify these gray areas and makes better choices easier.

timeline.storyText: The project started after several trips where Jade realized she had taken part in activities that were harmful to the ocean: too many boats around animals, corals stepped on, unclear practices‚Ä¶ This sparked a core question: how can we help travelers choose more respectful experiences? Jade then presented GuardianMap at the Altern‚ÄôUp competition and reached the final. Even without winning, it strengthened the drive to keep going. She brought Thomas into the adventure‚Äîafter working together on previous projects‚Äîto build a tool useful for both travelers and committed local operators.
timeline.missionText: To promote more ethical marine tourism, where each activity is chosen consciously. GuardianMap aims to highlight committed operators, share the right practices at sea, and propose itineraries that respect ecosystems and the communities who rely on them.
timeline.commitText: We select activities using clear criteria: recognized labels, trained teams, respect for wildlife, limited boat numbers, traveler education‚Ä¶ GuardianMap isn‚Äôt a showcase of everything‚Äîit‚Äôs a filter to spotlight the operators who truly make efforts to protect the ocean.

labels.title: Labels we support
labels.text: To select the activities listed on GuardianMap, we rely on recognized labels and structured initiatives, helping us highlight the most committed operators.

q1.a: No‚ÄîGuardianMap is not a travel agency. We highlight existing dive centers and operators, which you can then contact or book through their own channels.

q2.q: How do you choose the centers displayed on the map?
q2.a: We rely on official labels, commitments/charters, existing audits and, when possible, direct exchanges with operators. We prefer a strict selection rather than being exhaustive.

q3.q: If I see a problematic activity on site, can I report it?
q3.a: Yes! Your feedback is valuable. You can message us via the contact form or our social networks to report issues‚Äîor to recommend great operators to highlight.
